questions.text: A 10-year-old boy requires an amputation due to severe trauma to his ankle. The surgeon discusses two options: Syme’s amputation and Boyd’s amputation. Which statement accurately describes a key feature of each procedure?

choices.text: Syme’s allows for full weight-bearing; Children benefit greatly from Boyd’s.
Syme’s involves talectomy and fusion; Boyd’s preserves the distal physis.
Boyd’s involves talectomy and fusion; Syme’s uses a posterior flap.
Syme’s offers stabilization of the heel pad; Boyd’s is performed above the ankle.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Boyd’s involves talectomy and fusion; Syme’s uses a posterior flap.

 

Explanation:

Boyd’s amputation involves talectomy and calcaneotibial arthrodesis, while Syme’s amputation uses a long posterior flap.

 

Syme’s Amputation

Boyd’s amputation
  • Syme’s amputation is performed above the ankle. (Option D ruled out)
  • The level of bone section is 0.6 cm proximal to the ankle joint.
  • It preserves the distal physis, providing good function.
  • Children benefit greatly from this procedure. (Option A ruled out)
  • Men generally accept it well, but women may find it cosmetically unappealing.
  • The indications for the surgery are limited and it is technically difficult.
  • A long posterior flap is used, including the heel skin and fat pad.
  • The bones are cut just above the malleoli for stability.
  • Boyd’s amputation involves
    • Removal of the talus (talectomy)
    • The fusion of the calcaneus to the tibia (calcaneotibial arthrodesis). (Option B ruled out)
  • It enables full weight-bearing.
  • It offers stabilization of the heel pad while providing support for a prosthesis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a motorcycle accident. On examination, he has an open fracture of the right tibia with a 3 cm skin wound. There is moderate soft tissue damage, but no flaps or avulsions are present. Which Gustilo and Anderson classification best describes this injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Type II

Explanation:
The Gustilo and Anderson classification is used to categorize open fractures based on the severity of soft tissue injury and wound contamination.

 

 

In this case, the patient presents with a 3 cm skin wound and moderate soft tissue damage, which aligns with the Type II classification.

Gustilo and Anderson classification for open fractures

 

Type

Description

I

(Option A)

Skin wound less than 1 cm, clean, simple fracture pattern

II

Skin wound more than 1 cm, soft-tissue damage not extensive, no flaps or avulsions, simple fracture pattern

III

(Option C)

High-energy injury involving extensive soft-tissue damage, or multifragmentary fracture, segmental fractures, or bone loss irrespective of wound size, or severe crush injuries, or vascular injury requiring repair, or severe contamination including farmyard injuries

III A

(Option D)

Adequate soft-tissue cover of bone despite extensive soft-tissue damage

III B

Extensive soft-tissue injury with periosteal stripping and bone exposure

III C

High-energy injury and Vascular injuries requiring vascular repair and extensive soft-tissue damage

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with an open tibial fracture following a motorcycle accident. The wound is 4 cm long with moderate soft tissue damage but no flaps or avulsions. After an initial assessment, what is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient's injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Wound debridement and irrigation

 

Explanation:

  • Based on the management protocol of open fractures, wound debridement and irrigation are crucial initial steps in the emergency care phase.
  • This process helps to remove contaminants and devitalized tissue, reducing the risk of infection and promoting proper healing.

Management of Open fractures

Phase

Management Steps

I: Emergency Care
  • Control bleeding
  • Wound care: Wash the wound under strict aseptic conditions with clean tap water or saline.
    • Cover with sterile dressing.
  • Splinting: Apply a splint to immobilize the fracture and prevent further soft tissue damage.
  • Antibiotics & Tetanus prophylaxis
  • Pain management
  • Imaging: Perform X-rays to evaluate the fracture and to plan further treatment.

II: Definitive Care
  • Wound debridement: Perform thorough debridement of all devitalized tissue. This may need to be repeated.
  • Fracture reduction & stabilization:
    • External fixation: Provides stability and permits access to soft tissues. Useful for severe soft tissue injuries.
    • Internal fixation: Used for more stable fractures. Becoming more common in trauma centers.
    • Plaster immobilization: For cases with moderate-size wounds where stable reduction can be achieved.
  • Wound closure:
    • Primary closure: For clean wounds debrided within 6-8 hours.
    • Delayed primary closure: For doubtful wounds, observe for 2-3 days before closing.
    • Secondary intention: For infected wounds or extensive soft tissue damage.
  • Bone grafting: May be necessary for bone loss or to promote union.
  • Vascular repair: If vascular injury is present, repair is crucial for limb salvage.

III: Rehabilitation
  • Early mobilization
  • Joint exercises & muscle strengthening
  • Functional rehabilitation: Gradually increase weight-bearing and return to normal activities as healing progresses.

 

Management of open fractures based on grade:

  • Grade 1 is managed like closed fracture.
  • Grade 2 and 3a if clean and less than 6 hrs manage like closed, otherwise open fracture.
  • Grade 3b and 3c are managed like open fracture.

 

Internal fixation is typically performed after proper wound care and assessment of the fracture and soft tissue damage. (Option A)

  • It falls under the definitive care phase.
  • It is done for grade 1 and 2 and 3A less than 6hrs with clean wounds.

While splinting is important, it comes after wound care and is not the most appropriate next step for an open fracture. (Option B)

Administration of tetanus prophylaxis is important but not the most immediate next step. (Option D)

  • It should be given as part of emergency care, but wound debridement and irrigation take precedence.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is INCORRECT regarding malunion of fractures?

choices.text: Fractures in diaphysis are more prone to undergo malunion than fractures near metaphysis
The most common cause of malunion is improper initial treatment of the fracture.
Malunion in children always requires corrective osteotomy or osteoclasis to prevent functional limitations.
The clavicle and distal radius are common sites for malunion.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Malunion in children always requires corrective osteotomy or osteoclasis to prevent functional limitations.

Explanation:
Management of malunion in children does not always require surgical correction due to their greater potential for bone remodeling. Malunion in children, in certain cases, can be managed by a conservative approach by allowing bone to remodel itself.

Malunion:

Definition

Fracture healed in an improper position, leading to deformity and potential functional limitations

Common Causes

Improper initial treatment, inadequate reduction, unchecked muscle pull, excessive comminution

Common Sites
  • Clavicle
  • Distal radius (Colles fracture)
  • Supracondylar humerus
  • Long bones (femur, tibia)

Treatment
  • Adult- Often requires surgical intervention for significant deformity or functional impairment; corrective osteotomy is a common approach
  • Children- Greater potential for bone remodeling; management often more conservative; surgical intervention (osteoclasis or corrective osteotomy) reserved for severe cases or older children (Option C)

Factors Affecting Management
  • Age
  • Location of malunion (Metaphyseal fractures heal better than diaphyseal fractures)
  • Degree of angulation
  • Functional impairment
  • Plane of deformity

Option A: Metaphyseal fractures have better remodeling potential and are less prone to malunion compared to diaphyseal fractures.

Option B: Improper initial treatment is indeed the most common cause of malunion.

Option D: Clavicle and distal radius (Colles fracture) are common sites for malunion.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented with a history of a femur fracture from a road traffic accident 8 months ago. He was treated with a cast, but now has a deformity with leg shortening and limping. An X-ray shows abnormal alignment of the fractured bone. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) with bone grafting
Physical therapy to correct the deformity

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) with bone grafting

 

Explanation:

Malunion refers to the healing of a fracture in an incorrect anatomical position, leading to functional and aesthetic deformity.

  • In this case, the deformity is causing limping and leg shortening, which suggests that conservative treatment is insufficient.
  • The best approach is to correct the deformity surgically, with ORIF and possibly bone grafting to stabilize the bone.

Management of Malunion:

Management of malunion depends on the severity of the deformity:

  • Mild deformities may be managed conservatively with physical therapy or shoe inserts (for leg length discrepancies).
  • Moderate to severe malunions typically require surgical intervention:
    • Osteoclasis: Voluntary breaking of the bone - Bone is broken and the angulation is corrected, and refixed
    • Corrective Osteotomy: Cutting the wedge of the bone, correcting the angle, and fixing again. It is the gold standard treatment.
    • Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF): Osteoclasis is done then the angular bone is straightened and fixed with plates, screws, or nails to stabilize the corrected bone.
    • Bone grafting: If there is a bone defect or inadequate healing.

Option A: Conservative treatment will not correct an established deformity.

 

Option C: Physical therapy cannot reverse bony deformity but can only strengthen surrounding muscles.

 

Option D: External fixation is typically used for initial fracture stabilization or open fractures, not for correcting malunion.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with pain and inability to bear weight 10 months after a tibial fracture. Imaging shows a persistent gap at the fracture site with no signs of callus formation. Which of the following best describes this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Non-union

 

Explanation:

Non-union is the failure of a fracture to heal within the expected time frame, usually after 6-9 months, accompanied by pain and an inability to bear weight.

In this case, the absence of callus formation 10 months after injury suggests non-union.

 

According to the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, nonunion is declared when

  • A minimum of 9 months has elapsed since injury and
  • There are no visible progressive signs of healing for 3 months.

 

Muller and Weber Classification of Non-Union:

It is divided into

  • Vascular or Hypertrophic non-union: Excess callus is formed in between the proximal and distal fragments but does not bridge the fracture site.
  • Avascular or Atrophic non-union: Lack of vascularity - minimal or no attempt at callus formation.

 

 

Hypertrophic nonunion of the tibia

Atrophic non-union of the tibial shaft

 

A fracture is typically declared a non-union if it fails to unite after 6 months.

  • Distinguishing between delayed union and non-union requires progressive X-ray evaluation over time.
  • Mobility at the fracture site after a reasonable period strongly indicates non-union.
  • Pain at the fracture site during limb use is another sign of non-union.
  • Non-union may be painless if a pseudoarthrosis (false joint) forms between the fracture ends.

 

When a fracture takes longer than usual to heal, it is termed delayed union. (Option A)

Most delayed unions eventually heal, but in some cases, healing does not progress, leading to non-union.

 

Causes:

Mnemonic: 8 I and ABCD

  • Inadequate immobilization and reduction (Most common cause)
  • Ischemia: No adequate blood supply
  • Infection
  • Interposition of soft tissue
  • Intact fellow bone -
    • In case of tibia fracture, the fibula is intact
    • Fibula won't allow the contact of proximal and distal fragments.
    • Hence it will cause non-union.
  • Illness (systemic)
  • Individual bone susceptibility
    • Certain bones are susceptible to non-union as they are less vascular
    • Small bone with a high chance of non-union (scaphoid fracture)
  • Iatrogenic
  • Abnormal biomechanics of the bone
  • Bone loss
  • Comminuted and Compound fracture.
  • Distraction
    • Immobilizing a patient with skin traction
    • Distal fragment is tied to the weight or skin traction.
    • Due to excessive weight, the proximal and distal fragments will get distracted.
    • So, distraction should be optimal


 

Option A: Delayed union implies slow healing but not a complete failure to heal.

 

Option B: Malunion refers to improper alignment after healing. This patient's fracture hasn't healed, so malunion does not apply.

 

Option D: Pseudoarthrosis refers to a false joint that forms when non-union leads to abnormal movement at the fracture site and is usually painless. While this can occur after long-standing non-union, the patient is only 10 months out from the injury, so this doesn't describe the current condition.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a humeral shaft fracture that has not healed after 9 months despite conservative treatment. Imaging shows poor bone formation at the fracture site. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Continue conservative treatment with a brace
Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) with bone grafting

questions.solution:
Answer: C) Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) with bone grafting

Explanation:

For established non-union, surgical intervention is often necessary to stimulate healing. ORIF with bone grafting provides mechanical stability and promotes bone healing, especially in cases with poor bone formation.

Management of Non-union:

Non-union often requires surgical intervention, typically involving bone grafting with or without internal fixation. Treatment varies depending on the location of the non-union and the disability it causes.

  • Open reduction, internal fixation, and bone grafting:
    • This is the most common surgery for non-union.
    • Bone grafts, usually taken from the iliac crest, are used to promote healing.
    • Internal fixation with screws or plates is necessary in most cases to stabilize the fracture.
  • Excision of fragments: In some cases, removing one of the fragments is quicker and more effective than attempting union. This is only done when excision will not result in significant functional loss.
  • No treatment: Some non-unions are asymptomatic and do not require treatment, such as certain scaphoid fractures where the non-union does not cause significant issues.
  • Ilizarov’s method: Developed by Prof. Ilizarov, this method involves the use of a specialized external fixation device to treat non-union, especially in difficult cases.

Option A: Continuing conservative treatment with a brace is incorrect as conservative treatment has already failed.

 

Option B: Electrical stimulation therapy is sometimes used as an adjunct therapy but is not the definitive treatment in this case.


Option D: Intramedullary nailing can be used in some fractures, but ORIF with bone grafting is more definitive in non-union cases with poor bone formation.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the pathophysiological sequence leading to Volkmann's ischemic contracture in its most common location?

choices.text: Venous thrombosis → muscle edema → nerve compression → contracture of the calf muscles
Arterial insufficiency → compartment syndrome → myonecrosis → fibrosis of the forearm flexor muscles
Nerve entrapment → muscle atrophy → joint stiffness → contracture of the intrinsic hand muscles
Lymphatic obstruction → tissue swelling → collagen deposition → contracture of the upper arm extensors

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Arterial insufficiency → compartment syndrome → myonecrosis → fibrosis of the forearm flexor muscles

Explanation:

  • Volkmann's ischemic contracture typically results from a sequence of events starting with arterial insufficiency - Volkmann’s ischemia (often due to trauma like supracondylar fractures), leading to compartment syndrome.
  • This causes myonecrosis (muscle death) in the forearm, which stimulates fibroblast proliferation and ultimately results in fibrosis of the flexor muscles, causing the characteristic contracture.
  • Volkmann ischemic contracture is classically associated with a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. However, any fracture of the arm or elbow may result in this deformity.

 

Acute compartment syndrome is caused by ischemia of a closed compartment of the body (most commonly forearm) which leads to increased intra-compartmental pressure.

  • It may be due to a decrease in compartment size or an increase in the volume of the compartment.
  • Prolonged ischemia will lead to myonecrosis stimulating fibrosis resulting in a fibrotic pull of the wrists and fingers.

 

Causes include:

  1. Tight bandages and dressings
  2. Animal bites
  3. Burns
  4. Intensive and excessive exercises
  5. Muscle hypertrophy
  6. Neoplasms
  7. Bleeding into a closed compartment (injury to a vessel, congenital or acquired disorder)
  8. Injections in the forearm
  9. Surgery on the forearm

 

Common sites:

  • Most common: Flexor compartment of the forearm.
  • 2nd Most common: Anterior and deep posterior compartments of the legs.
  • Rare sites: Buttocks, shoulder, hand, foot, arm, and lumbar paraspinal muscles.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with flexion contracture of all five digits and the wrist, along with sensory impairment in the median and ulnar nerve distributions, following a supracondylar humerus fracture. According to Tsuge's classification, which stage of Volkmann's contracture does this presentation most likely represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Moderate stage

Explanation:

The given clinical presentation aligns with Tsuge's classification of moderate Volkmann's contracture.

  • This stage is characterized by the involvement of flexor digitorum profundus and flexor pollicis longus, often with additional involvement of superficial flexors.
  • It typically presents with flexion contracture of all five digits and the wrist, along with sensory impairment in the median and ulnar nerve distributions.

 

Clinical Features:

1. Initial Symptoms of Compartment Syndrome

  • Pain: The earliest symptom, worsened by passive extension of fingers - Stretch pain
  • Pallor: Skin may appear pale due to reduced blood supply.
  • Pulselessness: Diminished or absent radial pulse.
  • Paresthesia: Numbness or tingling due to nerve compression.
  • Paralysis: Weakness or inability to move fingers, indicating nerve ischemia.

 

2. Claw-like Deformity

  • Permanent flexion contracture of the wrist and fingers due to the shortening of flexor muscles.
  • Affected Muscles: Flexor digitorum profundus, flexor pollicis longus, and sometimes other flexors like flexor carpi ulnaris and flexor digitorum superficialis.

 

The Tsuge system classifies Volkmann contracture into the following three grades:

Mild

(Option A ruled out)
  • Localized contracture affecting parts of the flexor digitorum profundus.
  • Typically causes flexion of 2 or 3 fingers.
  • Commonly involves the middle and ring fingers.
  • Minimal to no sensory loss.

Moderate
  • Classic contracture - involves flexor digitorum profundus and flexor pollicis longus.
  • Flexor digitorum superficialis, flexor carpi ulnaris, and flexor carpi radialis may also be affected.
  • Muscle fibrosis leads to a claw hand deformity (flexion of all five digits and wrist).
  • Sensory impairment occurs in areas supplied by the median and ulnar nerves.

Severe

  • Involves both flexor and extensor muscles. (Option C ruled out)
  • Leads to severely distorted contractures with significant sensory deficits.
  • Long-standing moderate Volkmann contractures can progress to severe forms.


Threatened stage (Option D) is not part of Tsuge's classification for established Volkmann's contracture. It refers to the early phase of compartment syndrome before contracture develops.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with severe pain and swelling in his forearm after sustaining a crush injury 10 hours ago. He is unresponsive due to sedation, and compartment pressure measurements show 32 mm Hg. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Elevate the arm and monitor pain levels
Delay intervention for 24 hours to monitor for improvement

questions.solution:
Answer: B) Perform a volar fasciotomy

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with signs of acute compartment syndrome (ACS), indicated by the elevated compartment pressure of 32 mm Hg (Normal: 10 mm Hg) and the prolonged duration of pressure.
  • Emergency fasciotomy is required to relieve the pressure, preventing irreversible muscle and nerve damage.

 

Management of ACS:

1. Monitor closely for symptoms of compartment syndrome (Severe pain, swelling, numbness, tingling, muscle weakness).

 

2. Measure Compartment Pressure

  • If pressure is below 20 mm Hg: Conservative management.
  • If pressure is between 20-30 mmHg: Monitor closely for worsening.
  • If pressure is above 30 mm Hg or Delta P is less than 30 mm Hg: Proceed to fasciotomy.

 

3. Conservative Management (If pressure < 20 mm Hg or borderline)

  • Elevate limb to heart level - helps reduce edema and venous congestion without compromising arterial inflow.
  • Remove tight dressings or splints.
  • Monitor pain, swelling, and sensation.
  • Repeat compartment pressure measurements regularly.
  • Optimize blood pressure and hydration.

 

4. Monitor for Progression

  • If symptoms worsen or pressure rises above 30 mm Hg: Proceed to fasciotomy.
  • If symptoms improve: Continue conservative measures and monitoring.

 

5. Fasciotomy (If pressure > 30 mm Hg or worsening clinical signs): Volar Fasciotomy

 

 

6. Post-Fasciotomy Care - Wound care, physical therapy, and monitoring for complications (e.g., scarring or contractures).

 

Elevate the arm and monitor pain levels (Option A): While elevation may provide temporary relief, this is not the definitive treatment for compartment syndrome. Delay in performing a fasciotomy can result in permanent damage, including muscle necrosis and nerve injury.

 

Administer anticoagulation therapy (Option C): is not indicated for compartment syndrome, which is primarily a result of increased pressure within a closed fascial space, not due to vascular occlusion or thrombosis.


Delay intervention for 24 hours to monitor for improvement (Option D): Delay in treatment is dangerous. In cases where compartment syndrome is suspected, immediate fasciotomy is necessary to prevent ischemic damage. Waiting 24 hours could lead to significant muscle and nerve death, increasing the risk of permanent disability.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a history of forearm injury that led to Volkmann's ischemic contracture. On examination, the physician notes that the patient has mild flexion deformity of the fingers and some limited movement in the wrist but no significant pain. Which of the following treatment strategies is most appropriate for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Use of a turn-buckle splint

 

Explanation:

The diagnosis of established Volkmann’s ischemic contracture (mild type) is supported by the patient's history of forearm injury, which has resulted in a mild flexion deformity of the fingers and limited wrist movement without significant pain. This presentation aligns with Tsuge's Type-I classification, indicating that conservative treatment with a turn-buckle splint is appropriate.

 

 

 

 

 

Treatment strategies in an established Volkmann’s Ischemic Contracture

Mild Deformities (Tsuge's Type-I)
  • Use passive stretching with a turn-buckle splint (Volkmann’s splint).
  • This approach generally yields favorable outcomes.

Moderate Deformities (Tsuge's Type-II)
  • Perform a soft tissue sliding operation (Maxpage operation). (Option C ruled out)
  • Release the flexor muscles from their origin at the medial epicondyle and ulna.
  • May also include tendon slides and extensor transfer operations.

Severe Deformities (Tsuge's Type-III)
  • Consider bone operations like shortening of forearm bones or carpal bone excision. (Option A & D ruled out)
  • For severe contractures, perform extensive debridement of scar tissue.
  • Follow debridement with tendon transfer procedures to restore motion.
  • Transfer the brachioradialis tendon to the flexor pollicis longus for thumb movement.
  • Transfer the extensor carpi radialis longus to the flexor digitorum profundus for finger flexion.
  • Free muscle transplantation may be needed if the muscle belly is necrosed.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the principles of amputation technique?

choices.text: Skin flaps should be 1.5 times the limb width
For below-knee amputations, a longer posterior flap is preferred.
A tourniquet is always used, regardless of blood supply.
The fibula is cut 3 cm shorter than the tibia.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) A tourniquet is always used, regardless of blood supply.

 

Explanation:

A tourniquet is used unless there is arterial insufficiency, where it may not be appropriate.

 

 

Principles of Amputation Technique

  • Tourniquet: A tourniquet is applied to control bleeding unless there is a problem with blood supply, known as arterial insufficiency.
  • Skin Flaps: The combined length of the skin flaps used for the amputation should be 1.5 times the width of the limb at the site of amputation, ensuring adequate coverage. (Option A ruled out)
  • Flap Types:
    • For upper limb and transfemoral (above-knee) amputations, use anterior and posterior skin flaps that are of equal length.
    • For below-knee amputations, a longer posterior flap is preferred. (Option B ruled out)

Above knee and Below knee amputation

  • Muscle Division: The muscles are cut below the proposed area where the bone will be cut. These muscles are then sutured over the bone end to improve muscle control and blood circulation.
  • Osteo Myodesis: To strengthen the attachment of the muscles, sutures may be passed through drill holes in the end of the bone, creating a procedure called osteomyodesis.
  • Nerve Division: Nerves are cut under tension just above the bone to ensure that the nerve ends do not bear any weight, reducing the risk of complications.
  • Bone Cutting:
    • For transtibial (below-knee) amputations, the front of the tibia (shin bone) is beveled to create a smooth edge.
    • The fibula (the smaller bone next to the tibia) is cut 3 cm shorter than the tibia to prevent complications. (Option D ruled out)
  • Vessel Management: The main blood vessels are tied off to stop bleeding, the tourniquet is then removed, and any remaining bleeding points are meticulously ligated (tied).
  • Skin Closure: The skin is sutured together without putting tension on the wound, and suction drainage may be used to prevent fluid accumulation.

Stump Dressing: The stump is covered with non-constricting bandages to avoid pressure. Using figure-of-eight bandage passes helps to prevent a venous tourniquet, which can restrict blood flow.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man is recovering from a traumatic above-knee amputation. He reports that he sometimes feels as though his leg is still there, and he has episodes of sharp, shooting pain in that area. He also mentions feeling a tingling sensation as if his foot is still present. What condition is the patient experiencing?

choices.text: Phantom limb sensation and phantom pain

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Phantom limb sensation and phantom pain

 

Explanation:

The patient is experiencing both the sensation that his amputated leg is still there (phantom limb sensation) and the sharp pain in that area (phantom pain), which are common post-amputation experiences.

 

 

 

Complications of Amputation Stumps

Early Complications

  • Secondary Hemorrhage
  • Breakdown of Skin Flaps caused by ischaemia.
  • Gas Gangrene: Infection by Clostridia, especially in high above-knee amputations or reamputations performed through ischaemic tissue.

 

Late Complications

  • Skin Issues like eczema and ulceration.
  • Muscle Problems: Excess muscle at the stump can create an unstable cushion, necessitating excision of the excess soft tissue.
  • Blood Supply Issues: Poor circulation can result in a cold, blue stump prone to ulceration, particularly with below-knee amputations; may require reamputation.
  • Nerve Complications: Cut nerves form neuromas, which can be painful; excising 3 cm above the neuroma or freeing the epineural sleeve may help.
  • Phantom Limb Sensation:
    • All individuals with acquired amputations experience some form of phantom sensation, which is the feeling that the amputated part is still present. This sensation is most prominent immediately following amputation and gradually diminishes over time.
    • Phantom Pain: This refers to the awareness of pain in the amputated limb. Treatment for phantom pain is often difficult.
  • Stiffness or deformity above the amputation joint.
  • Bone Issues:
    • Bone Spur: Often forms at the end of the bone; usually painless but can become painful if infected.

Osteoporosis: Can lead to fractures in weight-bearing bones; fractures best treated by internal fixation.

 

 

Gas Gangrene (Option A): This is a bacterial infection characterized by severe pain and swelling, usually associated with deep wounds. The patient’s symptoms do not indicate an infection.

 

Nerve Neuroma (Option C): A painful growth of nerve tissue at the site of injury. The patient’s sensations of the missing leg suggest phantom phenomena rather than a localized nerve issue.

 

Skin Ulceration (Option D): Typically involves visible sores and redness due to pressure or poor circulation. The patient reports no skin issues, focusing instead on sensations in the amputated area.

questions.text: Based on the provided X-ray of the foot, identify the types of amputations indicated by labels 1, 2, and 3.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1- Pirogoff, 2- Chopart, 3- Lisfranc

 

Explanation:

1- Pirogoff, 2- Chopart, 3- Lisfranc correctly identifies Pirogoff at the upper level (os calcis fixation), Chopart through the mid-tarsal joints, and Lisfranc at the tarsometatarsal joints, aligning with their respective anatomical locations on the X-ray.

 

Chopart Amputation

  • Amputation through the mid-tarsal joints.
  • Allows for preservation of part of the foot while maintaining some functionality.

Lisfranc Amputation

  • Amputation through the tarsometatarsal joints.
  • Focuses on removing parts of the forefoot while attempting to retain as much length as possible.

Pirogoff’s Amputation

  • Involves fixation of the back of the os calcis to the cut ends of the tibia and fibula.
  • Only the anterior part of the calcaneum is removed.
  • Parts removed are
    • Forefoot
    • Midfoot
    • Talus
    • Distal part of calcaneus
    • Distal tibial articular cartilage
